column2: In spite of a delay for several years in embedding and sectioning the fertilized eggs for transmission electron micrographs, fixation and cell continuity was quite good, revealing a continuous outer dense fibrous layer (clearly visible below the gold coating for the scanning electron micrographs), and an inner amorphous layer (Fig. 22). When the hull presents a continuous barrier, as was shown in Tonicella lineata, the acrosome may contain more than one granule, and these are used up sequentially during penetration (Buckland-Nicks et al., 1988). Behavior of centrosomes during fertilization and cell division in mouse oocytes and in sea urchin eggs.
